BST, LEVEL 1 ROOM 223 DIV OF LAB ANIMAL RSRC
STONY BROOK, NY 11794

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
In November of 2024 several procedures involving oral gavage were conducted on a rabbit that had not been transferred
to the corresponding protocol.
Due to the lack transfer to the protocol containing oral gavage, veterinary and husbandry staff were not fully aware of the
study procedures the animal had experienced. For the IACUC to be able to fulfill its responsibilities under the AWA, the
IACUC must review and approve significant changes regarding the use of animals in ongoing activities prior to
implementation.
This incident was voluntarily reported to the USDA and corrective measures had been implemented prior to inspection. To
remain corrected after January 27, 2025.

On November 18, 2024, a rabbit was reported to the veterinary staff for diarrhea. Records available to veterinary staff did
not indicate any experimental use. The lab staff later alerted that the animal had been used experimentally, receiving
anesthetized oral gavage of study compounds on 11/15/2024, 11/16/2024 and 11/17/2024. Due to a lack of improvement
in the animal’s health despite veterinary care, the attending veterinarian decided the animal has reached endpoint. A
necropsy was performed by the veterinarian on 11/21/2024, an orogastric tube was found in the animal’s esophagus. The
IACUC investigation found that during one of the procedures the orogastric tube was not properly removed from animal.
Failure to handle animals appropriately can lead to trauma, behavioral stress, and physical harm. In this case the
improper handling of the orogastric tube led to the death of a rabbit. Handling of all animals must be done as carefully as
possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or
unnecessary discomfort.
This incident was voluntarily reported to the USDA and corrective measures had been implemented prior to inspection. To
remain corrected after January 27, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.31(c)(7) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
In November of 2024 several procedures involving oral gavage were conducted on a rabbit that had not been transferred 
to the corresponding protocol.  
 
Due to the lack transfer to the protocol containing oral gavage, veterinary and husbandry staff were not fully aware of the 
study procedures the animal had experienced. For the IACUC to be able to fulfill its responsibilities under the AWA, the 
IACUC must review and approve significant changes regarding the use of animals in ongoing activities prior to 
implementation. 
 
This incident was voluntarily reported to the USDA and corrective measures had been implemented prior to inspection. To 
remain corrected after January 27, 2025. 
2.38(f)(1)  Critical
   
Miscellaneous. 
On November 18, 2024, a rabbit was reported to the veterinary staff for diarrhea. Records available to veterinary staff did 
not indicate any experimental use. The lab staff later alerted that the animal had been used experimentally, receiving 
anesthetized oral gavage of study compounds on 11/15/2024, 11/16/2024 and 11/17/2024. Due to a lack of improvement 
in the animal’s health despite veterinary care, the attending veterinarian decided the animal has reached endpoint. A 
necropsy was performed by the veterinarian on 11/21/2024, an orogastric tube was found in the animal’s esophagus. The 
IACUC investigation found that during one of the procedures the orogastric tube was not properly removed from animal. 
 
Failure to handle animals appropriately can lead to trauma, behavioral stress, and physical harm. In this case the 
improper handling of the orogastric tube led to the death of a rabbit. Handling of all animals must be done as carefully as 
possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or 
unnecessary discomfort. 
 
This incident was voluntarily reported to the USDA and corrective measures had been implemented prior to inspection. To 
remain corrected after January 27, 2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
